After what seemed like an eternity forcing her way through the rampant undergrowth and hatefully uneven terrain of the jungle, Mipa reached the spot she’d been aiming for. The snare here too was sprung, but at least there was something in it!

It was the first trap that Mipa had checked so far today that had caught anything; granted, it was only the twelfth one she’d gotten to so far, how slow her pace had become. Some poor monkey had gotten its leg caught in the snare, some days ago by the smell of it for it was already dead. Mipa stepped forward gingerly, her flanks swaying to make room for bowlegged hindfeet to move move forward across her ballooning abdomen. She let out a little sigh of relief when she sat her fattened rear down on the ground. She nosed at her catch and licked her chops. Normally, she and Kovu would collect all the catches and take them up to her hollow to feed… But Kovu wasn’t here was he?

She didn’t give the matter too much thought before letting her stomach decide for her. The sight of fresh meat dangling in front of her was already making her mouth water. Ferociously, she reached up - her back flaring again slightly as she reared up - and grabbed the simian in her jaws. It was thicker and more hefty than it initially looked. Good. She bit through the leg and let the snare spring up with a clatter of shaking leaves as she settled down onto her wide gut to eat her meal alone.

She lingered there, under the snare, for a while absentmindedly licking the bones. It was less because she didn’t want to waste any of the meat on her catch than she wasn’t looking forward to continuing her rounds; let along resetting the trap beside her by herself. It was in this funk, after the surges of appetite had left her in peace, that she heard the sound. It was faint and it took her several long moments to recall what that peculiar sound was.

Mipa lifted her head away from her skeletal meal to hear it better. Thick and heavy bunches of skin hung from her throat and the underside of her jaw as she did and behind her head she could feel one or two of her permanent collars of flab shift against one another. It was a faint clack-clacky-clack sound; hollow bones. Then she remembered; Kovu’s windmill, his love for her.

He’d been up there to repair it twice now. It had only been a week or so since he made it, but already it needed repairs. “Failing,” a voice nearby whispered. “Just like your partnership with him.”

The well fed lioness turned swiftly away from sound of the windmill floating down into the oasis. She started for the voice was close at hand and even more, was quite familiar. Between her paws - past her generous brisket filling much of the space between that is - was the skeletal remains of her meal, held together by nothing but ligaments and gristle. But the hollow eyes of the empty cracked skull caught her attention. They gleamed.
121121121111111211111121112122.title: Faith Failing

1211211211111112111111211121221.content:
“Forgotten me already, have you?” Said Jobie. “I used to be your companion. Until you replaced me.” His voice was harsh in her mind and Mipa could not help but recall all the long lonely nights she’d spent by herself. When she’d felt utterly alone, Jobie had been there, no one but Jobie. “I was good company, wasn’t I? I didn’t demand anything of you like this Kovu. I never left you alone. Why did you leave me?”

“Jobie...” Mipa said, peering down into the lightless depths of the skull. “I have Kovu now. You’re... you’re not real. Kovu’s real.”

“How are you sure he’s not just a figment of your imagination, eh? Where is he now? What evidence is there that he even exists?”

Mipa looked around. Of course, there was none at hand. She sighed. “Jobie, I’m not that foolish-”

“You don’t need him, Mipa!” Jobie interrupted, “You need me. I kept you from being alone, and besides, look what he’s done to you!”

Mipa shied away slightly, but turning her head only allowed her to see her engorged flank spreading into view as well as feel the copious quantities of flesh draping from and surrounding her thickened neck. She could still hear Jobie speaking from the ground. “He’s turned you into a hippo, Mipa! He’s made you soft and slow and made it hurt to even walk and fix your traps.”

“Kovu didn’t do that, Jobie… I… I…” but she couldn’t bring herself to say it, even to Jobie. The shame was too great.

“He did do it!” Jobie insisted. “You’ve all but doubled your weight since you met him. How can it not be his fault? Think about all the food he’s offered you.” He said silkily. “He all but shoveled it down your throat… and the way he looks at you when you overeat… for him! He even said he likes the way you look as well. How ridiculous is that?”

The breath caught in Mipa throat from the tirade. Things she’d been blind to before suddenly seemed obvious. She could see Kovu for what he was, a charlatan, a user. Tears came freely to her eyes the more she thought about it. “He… He couldn’t…” she stammered meekly.

“He just wants to see how ridiculous you’ll look after feeding into his lies and then he’ll abandon you and you’ll be helpless.” His story seemed to bring the world into harsh illumination and made Mipa want to break down and sob, but suddenly Jobie’s presence was stronger than ever. It was as if he was just on the other side of her, a hair’s breadth away from touching her far flank. “It’s alright, Mipa.” He cooed. “It’s not too late.”

“T-too late for what?” asked Mipa.

“To leave this place. To just get up and go. Now.”

“W-what?” The very idea filled Mipa with terror. In her mind’s eye, the endless desert she’d almost died in spread out before her.

“Get up and leave, while the cad is still out hunting.” Jobie spat the last word.

“Where w-would I go?”

“Does it matter?” Jobie asked. Mipa felt an electric tingle up her spine at the ghost’s presence behind her. Jobie hadn’t seemed so real in almost a year. It was almost possible to imagine his former self standing behind her. “Wherever you go, I’ll be there, and that’s all that matters.”

Mipa was silent for a moment, considering the words of Jobie. Slowly she shook her head. She lowered her face to peer down at the little skull again. “Jobie… that’s crazy.”

The skull said nothing.

And the more she thought about it, the more she allowed herself to remember the past several months, the less convinced she grew that the matter was really as urgent as Jobie would have her believe. “I don’t need to escape Kovu.” She said finally. “He hasn’t done anything to hurt me and he’s had plenty of opportunities.”

“He’s not sincere.”

“And how do you know that?!” growled Mipa suddenly. Oh how she wished she could believe all of that dark maned lion’s sweet, sweet words. “Why on earth would he stick around this long, otherwise?”

“He only wants what all other males want.” Said Jobie in a low tone.

That was like cold water being dumped on her back. Of course it was true. She’d smelled as much, she’d felt as much… and yet… “Wait, you said that he was only pretending to desire me.”

“He is.”

“Then how could he want me for that as well?”

Again the skull had nothing to say.

Mipa took a deep breath and wiped her face with the back of a paw, it stung a little when she rubbed her cut cheek; she lowered her head as it was slightly more difficult to reach up against the thick fat of her shoulder nowadays. She spoke quietly once she’d cleaned away the tears. “Kovu said he loved me.”

“Lies.” Said the skull

“Kovu makes me feel good.” Mipa blurted before she was half aware of what she was saying.

“Kovu makes you feel afraid.” Countered Jobie.

And he was right about that. Every time he neared her... the thought of him coming closer... she was afraid. But then once he was there she felt so good. She needed him... he was good for her. He was right.

Jobie was not.

“I have Kovu. I’m sorry, Jobie.” Said Mipa, and inside, she felt something of a clarification beginning, a sense of tranquility regarding the future. Kovu still scared her, that much she could admit, but somehow she also thought that perhaps that was what she needed.

“You’ll regret not leaving him.” Said the skull, but already the voice was fading. She couldn’t feel Jobie behind her any longer.

“If I do then I’ll deal with it when it comes.”

The skull let out a final sigh. “I’ll always be here for you Mipa…”

Mipa smiled down at Jobie. “I know you will… You’re never more than a meal away.”

The skull grinned up at her and spoke no more.

Mipa sighed and slumped exhausted both mentally and emotionally. The thought crossed her mind to make her way back up to her alcove for a late afternoon nap, but the thought was also exhausting. She lowered her head down onto her paws, feeling her neck and brisket squish under her, and settled into an easy doze.
1211211211111112111111211121221.title: Return of Jobie

12112112111111121111112111212211.content:
Sleep peeled off the turgid lioness only reluctantly. In fact Mipa may have continued to lie in her spot beside the still-wet skeleton of her meal for a long while more if it hadn't begun to drizzle. It was only misting really, but the configuration of the canopy above conspired to drip a stream down on the fattened feline; right on her muzzle. Mipa got laboriously to her feet which at least weren't hurting as much now for the nap. For a few moments, she was torn between returning to the shelter of home in the alcove overlooking the rest of the oasis and finishing her round of trap checking.

But really, there wasn't a choice. Mipa simply didn't have the energy or the will to finish her hike through the jungle. She just wanted to lie down somewhere cozy and lick the starches she'd accumulated on her soft tummy a rub the still-stinging wound on her cheek. She turned to waddle back the way she'd come, not at all looking forward to the uphill fight against gravity that was to come. It turned out that gravity would be the least of her concerns, however.

Mipa had only taken a few steps when she realized that something was amiss. The disquieting stillness that had stolen over the jungle was noticeable even through the steady patter of light rain and the chimes of drips and drops that managed to find their way down to the ground. The birds and monkeys were not just being quiet, they were gone. Mipa hunched her fatty round shoulders and took small steps. Unease and fear filled her irrationally, even though she ought to be the biggest thing out in the jungle now that the ancient serpent was dead.

Mipa's fear only grew until she could continue no more. The silence surrounding her was deafening to the ears. Painfully slowly, she turned her huge self about in a circle, sniffing the sodden air, and looking every which way. She had the feeling of being stalked. She remembered it from the bad old times out alone on the savanna and in heat. And given her present state, how could she not expect some sex crazed male to be hot on her trail, even here, years after she thought she'd made her escape.

But it was not a male who stalked her.

There. Her eyes nearly passed over them, but there they were all the same, definitely not a trick of the eyes. In the shadows of the foliage beside a fallen palm tree she'd passed were a pair of sinister eyes. Cat eyes, and they glittered with their blue and yellow intensity right at Mipa.

It seemed for the longest time another nightmare come to play with her senses, an unreal thing like she sometime saw in her darkest moments. She stared at the eyes and they stared back at her and didn't move. And then they did. She stepped out of the leaves slowly, gracefully in an easy way that Mipa could no longer manage with her rolling, wobbling gait.

It was Mipa's turn to freeze, just like the forest.

What stepped out of the shadows could not be a better representation of everything Mipa was not. She was a lion, but thin and angular as a reed. Her ribs protruded from her flanks and her shoulders pumped like blades under her thin fur. For that, though, there was still ample muscle on her haunches and filling out her forequarters as well. She might have lacked a trace of body fat on her, and she looked fast and exceedingly dangerous. Everything Mipa was not.

She stopped before Mipa and looked at her down her nose, not saying a word. If anything, the mild expression on her thin face spoke of disinterested bewilderment. As if this stranger had come across some exceedingly odd variation of beetle and was deciding if stepping on it would yield an ounce of amusement or not.

Mipa couldn't take being sized up like that. And also, her knees were starting to hurt a little. She tried to speak but found her mouth unbearably dry. "He-He" she swallowed and tried again. "Hello?" she squeaked finally.

She was answered with silence. Inequitable distain shone in the strange lion's eyes as she continued to glance at Mipa as if continually surprised by her appearance at every new moment. Despte the lack of answer, and the pain in her knees, Mipa did not think for a moment about turning to go about her business. She wished desperately that Kovu were near instead.
Finally the stranger deigned to speak. "You're a curious thing," the stranger said and began to circle the bloated lioness. Mipa turned her head to keep her in sight, but couldn't seem to bring herself to move her heavy paws. Soon the thick fatty rolls she'd accumulated on her neck blocked her head from turning anymore. Mipa's extremely generous hindquarters felt hideously oversized and vulnerable. "Was your mother a hippo, and your father a lion? Or around here does food just walk into your gaping mouth?" The stranger asked as she came back around. Mipa noticed that she'd paused a little to sniff her crotch and surely realize her current condition.

Mipa gulped. "Please... I don't want any trouble." Her feet shuffled clumsily to shift the bulk of her a little away from the cold-eyed lioness. Her body moved in the way it should have if she were much thinner. As a result, she nearly tripped as her knee caught in her low slung belly.

The stranger didn't make a move to get nearer. Likely they both knew that there was no way Mipa was going to get away, even with a generous head start. "And you won't have any, not so long as you tell me what I want to hear anyway." She sat and looked at her paw as she slowly extended and retracted her claws, like knives. "I am looking for a lion, one with a black mane. I don't suppose you've happened to stumble across one have you?"

Kovu! Mipa thought agonizingly. What on earth is this female looking for him for? Mipa didn't have a whisper of an answer. "N-n-no… I haven't seen anyone like th-"

"You lie!" The stranger roared and surged forward. Mipa backed up, but the speed at which the lioness flowed over the ground was such that she'd barely taken two steps before they were face to face. Mipa's heavy rump fell to the ground with a dull Thud she and the other lion could feel in their toes. Mipa felt clumsy, heavy and useless and was in addition afraid for her life. "His smell covers you from your head to your toes!" Then, just as quickly as she/d dashed forward, she began to laugh. "He must have been desperate, this far out from home. Where is he?"

Mipa paused, terrible thoughts speeding through her mind. How did this lioness know Kovu? Was she... a former lover? Did Mipa have a rival? Panic welled up inside of her and her breath became ragged. Too many terrible thoughts were springing up in a whirlwind of confusion. It rendered her speechless. But it was clear that this lioness would not take silence for an answer. Claws withdrawn, the lioness boxed Mipa across the face. It was harder than Mipa could have ever anticipated. Her foreleg folded under the weight of her forequarters as she teetered off balance. Instinctively, Mipa reached out with one of her paws, but it didn't come close to hitting the stranger. Mipa collapsed painfully onto her flank and the lioness was on her in an instant, paws planted on her chest, and fangs close to her oh-so-squishy and tender neck.

"I'm going to give you one more chance to answer." she growled and Mipa could feel her claws sinking into her fatty hide on her chest. "Where is he?"
12112112111111121111112111212211.title: The Stranger

122.content:
This is a story about your average Everyman. Well... perhaps not so average because here we explore the everyday life of a common person, except this common person happens to also weigh in the extremes of the normal weight categories. However, his astounding weight doesn't really matter much to our protagonist. In fact, he gets along fairly well thinking little of his abnormal size, aside from all the little ways in which being large in a world designed for smaller frames.

I'm going to start with the name of John Avery, but you can change it if you wish during the course of the story. The main character must remain the same, however and no gender swapping. A female protagonist has certain qualities concerning attractiveness and self image that I want to downplay in this story. This is to be a study and a role play of what being at an incredible size might be like in real life.

In the spirit of this goal, please observe the following:

No magic and no unrealistic technology

No rapid wight-gain. If there must be WG, then make it extremely gradual, i.e. no more than 3 lbs a week.

No unrealistic eating. The main character has a normal appetite.

Try to keep extreme situations to a minimum. Remember, this is just your average guy with normal, everyday dramas.

The main character doesn't fondle himself nor does he fantasize about how big he is or how much bigger he will be. He is a man who is secure in his body shape and has gotten to his size through inattention or lack of maintenance. He is not a feeder or a feedee by nature. Not to say that he might not be introduced to the culture later

Finally, just try to keep his personality sane and not focused on the fatness. The point is to keep it in the background and let its effects show through subtlety. Thank you.

To kick this thing off, let's start by choosing one of the main features of John's life. His career...
122.title: John Everyman

1221.content:
Talk about low impact jobs! All you do is sit on your ass all day! No wonder it's so big... Eating most meals at drive-ins may not be helping much either, come to think of it. As a taxi driver, you don't have a lot of disposable income and being so big sure does have a tendency to make everything more expensive. More expensive clothes, different furniture, the food bills! The hours are long and you're unappreciated, but you get by your days somehow. You're grateful at this point that you don't have to spend your days on your feet. It's either this or driving a bus you guess...

Before we move on, let's decide one more important thing about John. Hold your excitement... Let's talk weight.

For the purposes of this story, lets assume that John has virtually doubled his weight since starting his job out of high school. How long he's been working, I'll leave up to you, but make it realistic, no less than 3 years.
1221.title: Everyone's Miss Daisy

1222.content:
Ah, the sweet taste of middle management! John's been at his job at his current job since getting out of college at age 21. He got a series of early promotions, but more recently has gotten only a series of lateral promotions and has been forced to take several pay cuts along with raises. He's put on a lot of weight in the intervening years as well and he is just starting to suspect that his lack of forward progress in the company might have something to do with that...

Before we get any further, let's decide another important feature about John. Something I'm sure you're all excited to hear. His weight!

For the purposes of this storyline, let's assume that he was at about 70% of his current weight when he started with his company and has since put on the remaining 30% in the five or so years he's been working.
1222.title: Dil-World

1223.content: The world is your oyster. pick and choose.
1223.title: Jobs...

12231.content:
The interwebz! You all know the power of the mighty net. John knows and he's been taking advantage of it since he dropped out of college to pursue an online business. He doesn't consider himself a failure, he learned a lot during his two years there, but since he swapped majors halfway through he decided to half his debt and jump into his career. John works from home, lives at home and has his groceries delivered to his front step. He doesn't own a car because he doesn't have a daily commute and doesn't want the expense. His inactive lifestyle has resulted in him really letting himself go and as his feet have gotten heavier... well, lets just say that he doesn't get out as much as he used to.

This is pretty much the ideal feedee's setup, but remember, John isn't a feedee and's he's not interested in gaining weight (currently!). He just doesn't really care about it. Although that may change...

Let's assume that John's weight has been creeping up on him for a long period of time, but his rate has been steadily climbing as he's gotten less active. John's actually put on more weight in the past 6 months than he had during the previous year. He's starting to wonder if he ought to do something about it finally.
12231.title: A Complicated Series of Tubes...

12232.content:
Teaching is an invaluable asset to our civilization, of that there can be no doubt. How can there be a future without teachers after all, and yet our society often leaves them with the shorter end of the stick. You know that well as a high school teacher. You also know that teenagers can be as much or bigger pains in the ass as their folks who pay your wages. You work in a private school, so things aren't as bad as they could be, but being different in the caldron of roiling hormones that is high school can be hell at times, even when you're the teacher. You sit when you lecture and point to the white board with either a laser pointer or a yard stick from your seat. And most of the students have pet names for you. "Mr. Whale." and "Prof. Gut." being the gentlest of these. But you bear through the teasing with a semi-light heart because you love what you do everyday.

Now, the part I know you've been waiting for. John's total mass!

For this story, let's assume that John gained most of his weight in his late teens and early twenties and has been stable for the last few years.

*I'm cutting out the 650 lb option cause I think it'd be real difficult to be an effective teacher at that size. If you feel differently, shoot me an e-mail with your justification and I'll open a spot for you.*
12232.title: The Greatest Minds of our Generation...

13.content:
Have you ever seen a stone-age goddess statue? If you have, one would think that our preferences are simply a throw-back to a by-gone era of gnawing on brontosaurus ribs... Anyway, before you conspire to lavishly wax on about how great being fat can be, think about what else is happening in the world and what problems your characters face. The engine of the story is conflict, Plot is the road it drives on.

Natii's Struggle
Natii is a tigress on the run. Forced out of home range by human expansion, this injured hunter happens upon an old, 'deserted' temple which at first seems like a good place to hide while she tries to recover. How will our striped heroine react when she finds out that the temple has much more to offer than mere shelter?

Katie's Fate
Katie is a moderately successful businesswoman, but when she spots an exotic statue in a second-hand shop, she has to make a choice, and as she finds out, it may be a 'bigger' choice than she realised, for she soon finds her life changing in a myriad of ways.

There are 3 story slots available. Please e-mail me your summary and title to edit your heading here.
13.title: The Fertile Goddess

choices: Natii awakes to to find herself much recovered
Natii awakes to find she's not alone
131.content:
Natii cursed as she limped through the forest, cursed the humans who'd driven her from her hunting-grounds, hounded her to the borders of her territory, and then tried to kill her, for what? For trying to feed on one of the bovines they'd begun to graze on her territory. The tigress also cursed the many other striped cats she'd cone across in her flight, unwilling to give even an inch of their precious territories to the injured cat, and adding their own injuries besides. Not that the scratches did much, she had to admit, but each stinging cut added its own flavour of pain to the feast of agony her other injuries were feeding her. The burns across her back and flanks felt like the fires there were still blazing, though they'd gone out days before, her mangled haunch sent spurts of agony up her spine with every step, and as if all of that wasn't enough, her stomach, now five or six days empty, was giving her no rest.

Suddenly, Natii's spirits lifted slightly as her nose picked up a faint scent; water! Moving as fast as her injured leg would allow, the tigress followed her nose and found, not just the stream she'd been expecting, but a pool, not a huge one, but rather deep for it's size, certainly deep enough to allow her to wade. Thanking the heavens vaguely for this gift, the injured cat stepped into the pool, following the bank down until with the ridge of her spine barely showing out of the water, her forepaws cold no longer touch the bottom. There she floated, enjoying the cooling, soothing sensation of the water on her wounds.

Natii floated in the pool for hours, not moving but for breathing and the occasional weak kick to keep her in the more-or-less middle of the watery heaven. The water also helped soothe her grumbling stomach as she drank several gallons of the cool liquid. The tigress knew she'd eventually have to get out of the pool though, but waited until nightfall to do so. Finally emerging from the pool, she shivered at the temperature drop, she wouldn't have noticed it in the pool, but out here, without the insulation provided by the water, the night air chilled her. For a while, she considered staying here, the pool would have made a nice focal point to her new territory, but after an investigation of the area she decided to leave, as nice as this pool was it didn't seem to be regularly visited, indeed it did not seem to have been visited in several moons.

Sad to leave, Natii slowly began to leave the waterhole behind. Normally she'd have shaken herself dry upon leaving the pool, but night the chill provided by the water within her fur seemed to dull the pain of her many injuries, which she considered more than a big enough reward. The tigress spent the night travelling as aimlessly as she had the past five days, and by morning, she was prepared to drop from exhaustion and pain. She temporarily staved off her slumber though, when she spotted a rather unnatural looking rock formation nearby. At first she wanted to run, things that were unnatural tended to involve humans, and humans were best avoided at any costs, but when a quick investigation found little evidence of humans, her fear was overtaken by her curiosity.

Moving closer to investigate the strange rock formation, Natii found to her surprise that while it did indeed bear the unmistakable touch of humans, no humans had visited for a long time, certainly there was no evidence of them beyond the rocks themselves. Her curiosity as satisfied as it was likely to get, the tigress immediately began to search for somewhere to sleep, eventually finding a place where the roof of a building had fallen in, leaving beneath the rubble a hole just big enough for her to turn around in, and completely sheltered from the sun. weighing the find up against the probability of finding anything else as inviting, she decided that the hole would do nicely, and so crawled in, and despite being unable to get comfortable, eventually drifted off to sleep.
131.title: Flight

choices: Natii decides to stay. (And become fat)
1311.content:
Natii awakes with a cramp in her leg and though she tries her leg will not move into a better position. Natii attempts to push her body out of the crevice she had slept in, but found much resistance to her movements though she made some progress. A few more three legged shoves pushes her out and into the early morning light. Natii ponders how she could fit in at night but not in the morning as her leg uncramps, when a glance at her side gives the unexpected answer. The scratches and slashes that had streaked her side were now healed to faint pink lines. Though startled by this, Natii has no time to think as her six day needs to be broken, and soon. She stalks off wishing for an early success. Midday produces a pair of very fat deer with seem to be thriving off of the lush grass and the absence of predators. Natii leaps attempting to hit the closest deer but she misjudged the needed jump and hits the deer with only her back paws though she does hit the seconded one with all four feet. After subduing the deer Natii turns to find the first stone dead on the ground.

Natii knows that it will be impossible to drag both deer back to the structure that she had dubbed "The Temple" and difficult with only one, but her near staved state hates to leave any amount of meat to rot. She also knows that while she could most likely eat both deer she would need to sleep soon after, and be in no state to fight should an enemy appear, however unlikely. With a plan in mind Natii digs into the second deer, to keep the blood from pooling and giving away the element of surprise next time. With a bulging stomach and the deer down to the organs, she prods around for a moment, snatches the heart and eats it. With the first deer in her mouth Natii drags it back towards "The Temple". The tigress thanks everything that she had circled around the temple and only stood a half-hour or less away from relative safety.

Natii drags the deer to the front of "The Temple" and sits it, and herself down in the warm sun set to gorge when a glint from the shadows caches her eye. The tigress stands a stalks off to the shadows. The glint came from a pool of water that had gathered in a low spot at the edge of the shade and so she dips her head and drinks a few swallows of cool water. Natii drags the deer over to the edge of the sunshine and sits down with her head in reach of both deer and water. Natii then eats about half of the deer before stopping to drink.

With the sun low in the sky Natii finishes off the deer and drinks till she can drink no more. With her legs spread out to give room for a gorged stomach Natii drops to sleep
1311.title: Natii awakes to to find herself much recovered

1312.content:
Natii awoke with a start and shook her head to try to dislodge the memories that seemed to have accumulated there. What a nightmare, she thought, I'm glad that's over. The tigress still felt uneasy for some reason though, and she quickly realised that she was in a place she'd never been, a dark plain under a dark sky. A dark silent plain what was more, she could hear not a sound around her, not the whisper of the breeze, not the insects chirruping in the non-existent grass, not the distant call of the night-flying birds and bats, nothing. Even more disturbing perhaps was the lack of light from the pitch-black sky, no stars, no moon, nor the fluffy texture of low-hanging cloud that would normally shield them from her.

Shivering with uncertainty, Natii stepped forward, and felt odd, there was ground beneath her feet, but it was smooth, solid, hard, like rock, though when she tested it with her claws it didn't score like stone normally would have, nor make a sound. Thouroughly disconcerted, the tigress was unable to contain her alarm any longer, and asked "is anyone there?"

Yes, I am, said a voice that seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere, and seemed to be as much a thought in her head as a sound.

"Wh-who are you," Natii asked, turning her head to try to find who had spoken, "Where are you?"

My name is Banka-Mundi, came the voice again, As for where I am, in this realm that question has no meaning, I am everywhere.

"This realm," Natii asked, "this place is different from the normal world?"

It is, Banka-Mundi replied, That realm you call the 'normal world' we refer to as the Mortal Realm, and this is the Shadow Realm, it is where we higher powers can best touch the minds of you lower creatures.

"Lower creatures," Natii asked, obviously disdaining the term, "and what are you? Gods?"

That definition will suffice, Banka-Mundi said, Though it is better to refer to us as higher beings, we disdain the term gods for the childish, petulant connotations humans give it.

"So what are you doing here," Natii asked, "and for that matter, what am I doing here?"

I am here because I am always here, now, Banka-Mundi replied, and you are here because you are asleep within the bounds of my temple.

"So this is all a dream then," Natii said, sounding relieved.

No, this is the Shadow Realm, Banka-Mundi said, You may describe it as a dream, but this is more real, as real as anything you've ever experienced; more real in fact, since your own mortal senses are fewer and more limited than they need be.

"It doesn't feel any more real," Natii said, "it does feel odd though."

You are not yet experienced enough here to understand, Banka-Mundisaid, with time and exposure you will learn, eventually.

"And in the meantime," Natii asked.

And in the meantime I must limit my expression to terms you can understand, Banka-Mundi replied, as demeaning and crude as such measures are.

"Demeaning," Natii asked sharply.

Had you known Spiritsong we could have concluded this 'conversation' in much less than a moment, Banka-Mundi replied, that you don't is only to be expected, but this 'language' is slow and crude.

"So you're here to lord it over us mortals," Natii asked not even trying to keep the irritation out of her voice.

No, Banka-Mundi said, You are wounded and weak, and will eventually starve without help.

"And you're offering me help are you," Natii asked, trying to hide her eagerness beneath her irritation.

In a manner of speaking, yes Banka-Mundi said, although it is more of a deal, for I too am weak, and crippled.

"So what's the deal," Natii asked.

I cannot heal your wounds, Banka-Mundi said, But I can provide for you so that it does not matter.

"And in exchange," Natii asked.

And in exchange you must take me to the humans Banka-Mundi said.

"No chance," Natii said, "Not in a million years am I going near those monsters again."

Then we are both of us doomed Banka-Mundi said, I beg you to reconsider, if only for your own gain.

"Why the humans," Natii asked, "why d'you need them?"

Once, when they worshipped me, I was powerful, the voice said, I could draw in whole herds, big herds that would be then penned and watered, or slaughtered and preserved, but no more, now I would struggle to draw in a single beast.

"Wait, worshipped you," Natii asked, "I thought you said you weren't gods."

We are not, Banka-Mundi replied, but worship does make us more powerful, in a way you are too ignorant yet to understand.

"So what, you want me to take you back to the humans so you can get big again," Natii said, "what's in it for me?"

Survival, Banka-Mundi replied, or the chance of survival anyway, against the certainty of death

"And how much of a chance are you giving me?" Natii asked, "You've already told me even one beast's a struggle."

To draw a beast in is hard, Banka-Mundi said, to make a beast, blind to your presence is easier, easier still if it's alone.

"I think I'm going to need a bit more help than that," Natii said, "I wouldn't have a clue where to start looking for prey out here."

I can help with that also, Banka-Mundi said, now, the deal?
1312.title: Shadow Realm

13121.content:
"I don't know," Natii said, "going near humans again is not something I'm comfortable with, not after what happened last time I tried it."

I understand your disinclination Banka-Mundi said but I promise you this, no human will harm you under my guardianship.

Natii agonised over the decision, she wasn't keen on having anything to do with humans, even with Banka-Mundi's promise, but the alternative was starvation; a painful, wasting death, made all the more so by her numerous injuries. Sighing, the tigress said, "Okay friend, it's a deal, but if they try to hurt me..."

You doubt that I will keep my word? Banka-Mundi said You obviously still have no inkling of what a boon this will be for me, and for you as well

The tigress sniffed where she sat on solid darkness. Rubbing her whiskers with a paw, she said. "And don't you know that insulting people isn't a very good way to earn their trust.

There was silence for a few moments, though the sudden prickling feeling on her back seemed to indicate to the tigress divine disapproval. Eventually Banka-Mundi said, Simply communicating in this manner is insulting in itself.

Before Natii could say anything, the goddess continued, But you agree to help me obtain new worshippers?

"…In return for my survival." said Natii.

Survival for the both of us. Said the hidden entity. …And more besides. Even now I have some power left to me. It will only grow as the old faith spreads once more. You should be honored to be a vessel for a being the likes of I.

Natii slanted her eyes. The large cat was still having doubts about the ability of this bodiless fiend to safeguard her life. But then it was hardly as if she had anything to lose right? However the spirit had stumbled onto a topic which piked her interest. "So you're telling me you're going to give me powers?" The tigress's tail lashed behind her, "What sort of powers exactly?"

The hidden voice hesitated for only a moment. A couple I already described, drawing in creatures from the wild and rendering prey deaf and dumb to your presence. But that is hardly the extent of my prowess. Banka-Mundi elaborated. You will gain other abilities once my strength begins to return to me. Natii was - perhaps a little immaturely - imagining herself flying over the tops of the trees and viewing the world as a bird does when the goddess continued. You will have to relinquish control to me on occasion, of course.

That didn't sound good. "What do you mean by that?" asked the large cat, still futilely studying the featureless dark of this place.

There was a whisper of a sigh before Banka-Mundi spoke. I mean just what I say. At times, I will need to act through you and when that happens, you will need to surrender your body to me.

"You mean possess me…" Natii shivered a little at what she was hearing.

Semantics. said Banka-Mundi It is what it is, no matter what you call it and this is how things must be if you want to survive.

Suddenly Natii was not so sure she wanted anymore to deal with this invisible Banka-Mundi. She turned her head around, but the area behind her was just as black and impenetrable as the region in front.

As if she were able to sense the tiger's hesitation, Banka-Mundi spoke in a less harsh voice. It is not such a large thing that I ask. Your fleshy container is not you, certainly. You shall not lose yourself. And I swear that this will only happen on occasions when a display of power is necessary.

Natii frowned. By the moment, she felt increasingly as if she were dealing with a demon; and really, if the surroundings were anything to go on, Natii was not entirely sure she wasn't. "And how do I know you will keep your promise?"

The very air quivered and Natii realized that Banka-Mundi was chuckling. You must think highly of yourself, little hunter, if you think I would be interested in occupying such an insignificant little vessel such as yours. No you shouldn't fear me desiring to displace you…

The air continued to vibrate in the goddess's mirth and Natii did indeed feel small and insignificant. She looked at her paws and could at least see those clearly. If it was an act, it was a good one, the tigress had to admit. The very idea of taking over her body seemed to have the goddess quite amused as the atmosphere continued to thrum. The tigress didn't know whether to feel comforted or insulted.

When the vibrations dissipated, the goddess spoke again, Do you accept offer then, little hunter?

Natii shut her eyes and considered for several long moments. The realization she came to at last that outweighed all other concerns was the fact that she didn't want to die. "I do accept, Banka-Mundi. However I reserve the right to cancel our deal if I find it displeasing in the future."

There was a low grumbling, like the grinding of rocks the size of mountains on the other side of the world. Hmm… I will accept your condition, but only if you agree to let me know ahead of time, so that I may consider how best to end our arrangement.

That sounded fine to Natii. "Very well, we have an agreement!"

The dark void surrounding Natii seemed to brighten, the tigress took this to mean that the goddess was pleased. Good… drawled Banka-Mundi. Now sleep, you will have a long day ahead of you tomorrow…

All of a sudden, it felt like the ground was swept out from under her paws and Natii was falling, if one can fall without a breeze, that is. After a few moments, it felt more as if she were floating than falling, a warm nothingness cradling her body. The tigress felt fatigue crawl up her spine and throughout her body and she stretched and then curled up. Sleep took her then and in her mind's eye, Natii saw herself as a tiny golden mote in a vast sea of darkness she hadn't the least comprehension of.

-------

Natii awoke slowly at first, groaning at the aches and pains in her body, then suddenly all of was replaced by an agonising burning in her flank that awoke her very quickly. Rubbing her burned flank against the roughness of the stone felt as if someone were taking a blade to her flesh. Struggling to manouver herself in the confined space, the pain stirred her to greater speed, but the tigress attained numerous more scrapes and bumps in getting out of the tight hole. Checking herself over in the light of mid-morning, once she was out in the courtyard again, she was rather displeased to note the numerous oozing wounds her exit from the hole had opened, especially where her fur had been singed away. That was the last time she'd sleep in there, she decided, until her wounds were rather better.

She spent a good long while licking herself, though she had to go gingerly on the wounds as even the roughness of her own tongue was often too much for them. As she groomed herself, Natii could not help wondering if everything she had experienced last night had been nothing more than a fever dream. She was certainly too wounded to dismiss the possibility. After grooming herself thoroughly, however, her thoughts turned naturally to food and her long empty belly. That was when she received confirmation for last night's vision.
13121.title: Done Deal

13123.content:
"Do I have to make a decision just yet" Natii asked "because I'm really not hooked on the idea of going back to the humans, not after last time."

No, you do not have to decide yet Banka-Mundi replied I will not rush you.

"Yeah, okay" Natii said slowly, then, trying to distract herself "so how do senses work here, if they're supposed to be better than back in the real world?"

Senses, in the way you mean them don't exist here Banka-Mundi replied here you can 'see' and 'hear' and 'sense' as much as your mind will accept, you only appear to have the 'normal senses because your mind does not yet understand the Shadow Realm.

"Then how do I make my mind understand" Natii asked.

That will come with time Banka-Mundi said but I will try to help you.

"Good" Natii said "what first?"

Thought speech might best be first step Banka-Mundi replied try thinking of what you want to say, rather than saying it out loud.

What, like this Natii though, trying hard not to say the phrase out loud.

Yes, very much like that Banka-Mundi replied it will take you a while to get used to it, it always does.

"How long-" how long is 'a while' Natii asked.

Several trips perhaps Banka-Mundi replied there is no way to tell, some people get used to it more quickly than others, I think you may be one of the faster ones.

Oh goody Natii thought sarcastically "I'm-" I'm sorry, did I just think that?

You did Banka-Mundi replied but again, learning how to keep such thoughts private will come with time.

To take her mind off the embarrassment Natii asked are there any other fairly easy things to learn?

Shadowsight ought to be fairly easy Banka-Mundi replied now do you see the point of light over there?

Over where...oh, there, that shining white dot Natii asked is that the one you were meaning?

Yes it is Banka-Mundi replied now try focussing on it, try seeing it as it really is, not as your mind expects your eyes to see it.

Natii quinted, or tried to, I'm sorry, I don't-

No, don't try squinting or anything like it Banka-Mundi said those don't work her, focus on it.

Natii struggled unsuccessfully for a few moments, and was about to give up when something suddenly clicked, and there was the ball, seemingly an inch from the end of her muzzle, crackling and sparkling. It was only there long enough for the shock to take effect, then it vanished and became again a distant shining. "Good grief" she said "did I just-" did I just see that?

It can come as a shock the first time, can't it Banka-Mundi said sympathetically don't worry, you'll get used to it with experience.

Natii was silent for a good while, then finally asked can I use down there in the real world?

In the Mortal Realm, yes you can Banka-Mundi replied it's harder though, because your physical senses will constantly interrupt you concentration.

But I could use it to find prey couldn't I Natii asked I mean, if I really needed to.

It would take a great deal of time Banka-Mundi there are ways of speeding it up though, which I will tech you eventually.

Not yet Natii asked, disappointed.

No, not yet Banka-Mundi replied there is still much you need to learn before you can make proper sense of it.

Oh Natii said well, what sort of things do I need to learn?

You first need to learn how to control your Shadowsight Banka-Mundi replied and then how to sense distance while doing it.

Well, practice makes perfect I suppose Natii said could you give me something a bit less, energetic to practice on though?

I will endeavour to do so Banka-Mundi replied, then after a few moments, said do you see that?

I think so, yes Natii replied, noticing a slightly duller white dot a way away.

Good, Banka-Mundi said, now focus on it.

It took Natii several moments to understand what she needed to do, then the stone appeared in front of her, this time a foot from her muzzle, am I...

Yes, you're doing it Banka-Mundi replied and quite well too considering how little practice you've had.

It almost looks like I could touch it Natii said unintentionally.

Why don't you try to then Banka-Mundi said.

"What" Natii said, her concentration suddenly disrupted "did-" did you just say something?

Yes Banka-Mundi replied you said it almost looked like-

I didn't say that did I Natii asked I hadn't meant to say it.

You will learn Banka-Mundi said and now, the stone again, and this time try to touch it, you may be surprised.

Trying to take her mind off her recent embarrasment, Natii concentrated on the stone, calling it up much more easily now that she knew vaguely what to do. For a few moments the tigress held it there, and then inquisitively, reached out a paw gasping as she felt its rough surface beneath her paw. The surprise, shock even, was enough to disrupt her concentration, but as the rock snapped back to its distant point, she was left with the memory of the roughness "did I-" did I just...

Yes, you did Banka-Mundi said easy, wasn't it?

But, but it's so far away Natii said how could I have...

Distance here is not as limiting as in the Mortal Realm Banka-Mundi explained it still exists, yes, but there is nothing physically preventing you from crossing many miles in a single leap.

But, how can that be Natii asked I don't understand.

You will, eventually Banka-Mundi said calmly was silent for a moment, then added or perhaps not so eventually, you see this?

Do I s-where'd that come from Natii asked, recoiling at the large white stone that had suddenly appeared beside her did you create this?

In a sense, yes Banka-Mundi replied although create is not quite the right word, nevertheless, climb it.

Why Natii asked warily.

It will help you to, understand Banka-Mundi said go on, it's quite safe.

Uncertain, but at least slightly reassured, Natii did as Banka-Mundi instructed leaping easily onto the stone now what?

Now, focus on the other stone Banka-Mundi instructed bring it near, and then jump to it.

Jump to it Natii exclaimed But it's so far-

No Banka-Mundi said it is as near as you imagine it to be, as I explained.

Natii was silent for a moment, then said uncertainly well, here goes. Drawing the other stone close with her mind, the tigress moved it to what she thought was a reasonable distance, and then bracing herself, leapt. There was a moment's uncertainty as she landed, and then she looked around for the rock she'd just come from, now a white dot on the horizon did I just...

Yes, you did Banka-Mundi replied

"B-but" that's impossible Natii stammered, more than a little frightened.

It is only because you perceive it to be said Banka-Mundi in the Shadow Realm, perception is everything, If you perceive a great distance to be short, then it is.

Natii shook her head in confusion, and said but that's not how things work in the real world!

The was a slight pause and then Banka-Mundi spoke you would be surprised, young one. And again, this place is just as real as the Mortal Realm, and in some ways less odd.

But Natii was still staring at the distant white rock on the horizon, the one she had been sitting on just moments before. The world seemed to be spinning. Banka-Mundi...I... Natii managed despite the sudden vertigo I-I'm not sure...I can do this...

All things in time Banka Mundi said, but now it is time for you to return to the Mortal Realm

On those words Natii, overcome with dizziness, and fell from her perch on the white rock. The ground didn't break her fall, however, she just kept tumbling down...down...

Sleep... Natii...

***

Natii drew in a breath with a gasp. The air was warm and humid and stank of crumbling masonry. Wincing, the tigress again felt the many aches and pains coursing through her damaged body. She was awake, alive again. It had all been just a dream.

Or had it? Natii crawled forth from her hole and sat her haunches down on some smooth, mossy stone, carved long, long ago by human hands; humans who had once worshipped a goddess named Banka-Mundi. The tigress felt the hollowed stones under her paws and closed her eyes. She exhaled and tried to remember what that place she'd visited in her dream had felt like, tried to recall the feeling. It was hard because of the pain she was in, but she tried anyway, not knowing if what she was doing was foolish or not. She breathed in. Banka-Mundi Natii asked in her mind.
13123.title: Explaining Shadows

131232.content:
Natii waited for a response... and waited. She let out her breath and rubbed her eyes with a paw, though reaching up pained the burns she had on her back. Still, the tigress felt this was important enough to try again. She calmed her breathing, closed her eyes and focused, bringing her mind back to that dark, still place. Banka-Mundi... she thought into that blackness in her mind.

The answer was so faint and indistinct, Natii thought she might have been imagining it. But she chose not to believe the voice was a figment of her imagination. Little Hunter...

Though this supernatural being was strange and the things she had shown her were strange, Natii could not help but feel uplifted at this small measure of success and validation of what she had experienced while she was asleep. "Now you said you were going to help me." said Natii aloud to the empty ruins. She'd taken three breaths before she realized her error. She swallowed and again tried to focus her mind, but now that she was awake, she found that the black, silent place was hard to find amid the buzzing of insects, the light behind her eyelids and the pains infecting her body. You said you were going to help me. Thought Natii at the sickly goddess. She sounded demanding, even in her own mind, but being awake reminded the tigress what a grim situation she was in.

Again, Natii was not sure if she was imagining the voice or not, but the blackness seemed to answer, East... east... The voice gave the direction and furthermore, Natii sensed that the goddess's destination was not far, quite close in fact. That was good. Natii did not think she had the strength anymore for much wandering. The injured tigress got crookedly to her paws and limped across the green stones. An archway led out the intended direction and into the jungle proper. It was twilight and the beginning of a new day.

Try as she might, Natii could not summon up Banka-Mundi's voice again as she walked. But she didn't stop or concentrate too hard, instead trying to make as good a time as possible, so it didn't bother her much. In fact, Natii was a little relieved to again have the privacy of her mind restored so she could dwell properly on the goddess's proposition.

Gods were not beings to be trifled with, either your own or others' and even though Banka-Mundi had said she was not one, she still bore an incredible resemblance. And furthermore, she desired worshippers. That scared even the large cat. She was no priest. She had no idea what she was getting herself into. It was like leaping into a gulf without checking to see how deep it was first, or if there was water below to catch her. The cautious side of her just wanted nothing more to do with Banka-Mundi or shadow realms or the like.

And yet Natii limped as she walked and cuts and bruises and burns ravaged her once beautiful coat. She hadn't had anything to eat in a week... and she was starting to feel the deathly weakness infiltrate her body. How could she hunt like this? Her common sense told her she was not long for this world. The sense of impending doom wanted to make Natii cry. She'd never thought the world fair, but that didn't make her anymore prepared to accept her fate as a ruined hunter. "I don't want to die! Damnit!" she wept.

The tigress paused to rest, her injured leg was hurting too much and the depression threatened to overwhelm her. Although the jungle was noisy and busy with life all around her, the tigress could see nothing but her own death ahead of her. And it was just as Banka-Munid had said. Accept her proposal or die... strong incentive indeed. But still, in Natii's experience no one ever gave away something for free, and she was sure that a being as old and obviously wise as the goddess of hunting and fertility would benefit the greater from the bargain.

Natii closed her eyes and leaned against the damp bark, waiting for the ache to fade. She wondered what a half-dead god could do anyways. She doubted that even she could save such a wretched cat as she. As Natii relaxed however, the blank slate of her mind seemed to peel away, revealing a rippling image. It was an elderly chital, lying down amid some broken branches and a patch of nettles. She looked stringy and thin, but still quite delicious. She is dying. came the familiar not-voice. she is waiting for a hunter to deliver her peace.

Natii was already struggling to rise. Not only was she hungry now, but the matter had suddenly become one of honor as much as an easy meal. It was a sacred understanding that the hunter was to usher her prey into the next stage of rebirth, especially when that animal was in pain. Natii tried to still her mind, Where is she? Where...

But Natii heard nothing and the tigress was driven half mad by a desperate need to find the ailing deer. She set out, listening, looking and sniffing the breeze. She was sure that the goddess would not have shown her the vision if this needy creature was not nearby.

With her leg hurting her at each step, it seemed futile to search, however luck seemed to be with her... or else another force entirely. Natii had set out in the right direction and she was able to pick up the chital's scent when she crossed it. It only took a few seconds to know which way the old deer had gone. Natii followed the scent of her prey's footsteps.

The tigress pushed her way through brush and brambles and along the way, she was filled with the sense that the chital was choosing a place to die. Natii pushed herself, although the brambles made the going slower and more painful for the bigger tigress. The scent of the chital laced through all the nettles ahead of her. And then suddenly, there she was, just as Natii had seen in her vision.

The chital lifted her head to look at Natii, her eyes watery and filled with even more pain than the tigress herself. The big cat understood somehow that the small deer was dying of parasites in her gut eating her from the inside. She was ready and she was grateful that someone had come. Natii took a few steps forward and descended on the chital. She took her neck in her jaws and broke it with a sharp twist of her head; the chital's spine felt as insubstantial as a twig. When the deer went limp, Natii finally felt at ease. Her duty was complete.

Natii let go and heaved a sigh. The tigress felt approval from someone distant and yet not far away at all, and something more; mutual understanding. Natii crouched and began to eat. Although they had not spoken, she would not soon forget the chital who had saved her life.


There was not a whole lot of meat on her, though the tigress was not complaining. The disease had mostly consumed the chital before Natii had arrived. Still, it was more than she'd had and the hunter was grateful. However, the sight of the putrid innards which filled the chital's distended abdomen disheartened the tigress; even the liver was fouled. The skeletal muscle and the hide and brain would have to do. She spent three hours cleaning the corpse of everything eatable and at the end of it all, she rested on a comfortably distended stomach. Her meal was good to keep her for the next day and a half, though she could go three if she had to, Natii supposed. Right now, all she wanted was another long nap. She'd only been up a few hours, but her body was hurting her and her full tummy was making her drowsy. Natii didn't feel lazy, it was simply the way of cats.

Not even caring that she was bedding down in a small clearing in a patch of brambles, Natii curled up to nap. As she faded, her thoughts were on the faceless goddess who had brought her this boon and what she might ask in return... Secretly, Natii hoped that Banka-Mundi would not be able to pull her into the shadow realm outside the ground of her temple, but didn't put much stock in that particular hope.
131232.title: Savior

choices: "Well if it's not too much trouble"
1312322.content:
Natii dreamed of her home territory. It had been a lush place in her mother's time, or so she'd told her. Every year the river would swell so wide that one could barely see across it, but with it, brought enormous bounty for every creature. The jungles of West Bengal are vast and Natii had just a tiny portion along side the western bank of a great river, but it was her portion. Her mother had told her than their line had dwelled in the area for untold generations. It was good land.

...Or at least it had been. Tall apes with loose, often smelly outer layers draped across their bodies came. They'd always been there and Natii had heard tales from tigers passing north through their territory; horrible stories. They told of demons who knocked down the jungle, laying the earth bare and filling it with segmented pools for the growing of rice or else tempting open pastures teeming with fattened cattle which seem just ripe for the picking. But there was a curse across all the human lands and a tiger, no matter how formidable was ever safe there. Just prowling in the open could result in one being struck dead on the spot. A terrible crash like thunder was the only warning. They told Natii that if she ever saw a human she should run, especially if they have skin as pale as the moon, as pale as death.

Natii had scoffed at such ghost stories and her mother had shooed these traveling tigers on through their territory. Both mother and child were far too busy with the business of hunting and maintaining their territory to pay any heed to such fanciful tales. Her mother had learned the hard way the validation of the stories...

The wounded tigress tossed and turned in the night. She didn't want to think of the fire nor the destruction. With a deep breath and a relaxing of her spine, she changed the dream, escaping into the deeper past.

Natii found herself sunning on a rock which was all too familiar to her. It was her favorite sunning place both because a fallen tree had opened up a great hole in the usually omnipresent canopy above and because the shape of the rock was extremely comfortable and usually dry. She felt the warm touch of the sun on her back like it was new and she let out a sigh, stretching her body languidly over the firm surface of the rock cupping her body.

Natii was only an adolescent, so her mother was out hunting. Janani had gone west, away from the river, she she was likely searching for jungle boar in the dips between the near hills, it was their rutting season after all. They would be incautious and fat to boot.

The tigress rested her chin on a small flat prominance in the stone. She wasn't reliving this memory, she remained aware of the next 18 months of her life and the great amount of ruin which had come upon them so suddenly. She wished that she wasn't. She wished that she could forget that this was a dream and choose to believe that nothing bad had happened. Natii felt like weeping for the beauty of the green ferns and tall trees surrounding her, but the dream lent her a measure of comfort. She was in the past, and those things didn't have to be here if she didn't want them to. And Natii didn't. They were all too fresh in her waking mind already.

Natii was interupted in her brooding by a breaking twig. She perked her head up to see a newcoming entering the small clearing around the hulking mass of the fallen jungle titan. Natii got to her knees and crouched on her rock. It'd take a foolish creature indeed to stumble upon a hungry tiger, either that or unlucky. It didn't really matter at this point. The tigress's pulse quicked when she saw the shape of the deer and she licked her chops. But then she saw who it was, and remembered.

Natii was stunned to see the chital that she had killed and eaten not more than a few hours ago. "Why is she here in my dream?" Thought Natii curiously.

Then the Chital spoke in a quiet, unassuming voice. "Is this your home?" she lifted her head slightly to take in the surroundings. "It's quite beautiful."

Feeling confused at the presence of someone she only just "met" in her dream, all the tigress could say was, "You don't belong here."

"I know," the Chital said, "but I wanted to thank you for the kindness you showed me."

"Kindness..." Natii asked, turning her head uncomfortably, "but I killed you for myself, for what little of you I could still eat."

The chital did shift her front hooves a little in the soil, but admitted, "That's nature. I don't hold you accountable for doing what you have to to survive, anymore than I imagine the grass blames me for eating it. Besides, I was in terrible pain. What you did for me was a mercy."

Natii relaxed and then sat on her haunches, relishing the lack of pain. "That's certainly an enlightened point of view." she said and then lifted a paw, "And while I'm grateful that you're not holding anything against me, I can't help still wonder why exactly you've come here... if, in fact, you are not just a figment of my imagination."

A frown crossed the small deer's face and then she charged. Too shocked to move at first, Natii had to ward off blows from sharp, light hooves when the chital reared up and started kicking her with her front hooves. The tigress leaped back from the assault and onto her rock. She growled and was about to reciprocate the attack when the chital relaxed. She was not out of breath and said, looking up into the tiger's eyes, "Would a figment of your imagination do that?"

Natii licked her forearms where she's received the kicks. The little nicks and scratches did sting. "I suppose not..." she said between pulls with her wide, scratchy tongue. "But still... why have you come? Don't you have better things to do now that you're dead?"

The small deer back up a couple paces and the tigress looked at her curiously. She seemed uncomfortable all of a sudden. "I did... I mean I do, but..." the chital sniffed, "You were right here and I felt I ought to do something."

Natii crossed her front paws and rested her head on them, looking down on the chital from the high rock. "And what exactly is that?"

"I thought I should... warn you." the Chital replied,

"Warn me," Natii asked, lifting her head in surprise, "of what?"

"Of something coming from the west," the Chital replied, "I don't know what it was exactly, it seemed pretty weak, but I am sure it was trying to come for you."

In the west? But in the west lay... Natii thought about this, surely the goddess, already so weak within her temple that she could barely be heard during waking was utterly incapable of spreading her influence this far. Nevertheless, the thought sent a slight chill up her spine. "You stopped it?" she asked.

"I think so yes," the Chital replied, "It sure didn't seem to like the territory of your mind. It stuck to the shadows."

"Then it is I who must thank you," Natii said, "and now I wish you safe travel on your journey, wherever that leads."

"You do not wish me to stay around?" the Chital asked again shifting her hooves in the loam, "Whatever it was that came for you may try to come again."

Natii considered this, if indeed it was Banka-Mundi that had tried to come for her then there was no may about it, but now that she knew that something had tried to come for her she'd be ready.
1312322.title: Old Home, New Friend

132.content:
Katie was just window shopping down the main street when she found it, a statue in what looked to be polished green marble with some gold-leaf decoration. She almost walked past it, sitting there in the window of the antiques shop, but just as she was drawing abreast of it, the light caught the gold, making it glitter, and catching her eye. Stopping to look, the young woman saw that the piece must be new, it looked unusually fresh compared to the sun-faded goods in the rest of the window. About six inches high, it seemed to be a cross between a 'fat old man' buddha statue and one of those stone-age fertility idols. Her curiosity piqued, she decided to enter the shop and enquire about it.

A bell tinkled as Katie opened the door and entered the shop, which drew the attention of the old lady behind the counter, "oh, hello miss, and how can I help you today?"

"I was just wondering about that statue in the window," Katie replied, "it looks new."

"It is," the old lady replied, "I was given it only last week, young man came in, purporting to be from the Luckmann estate."

"The Luckmann estate," Katie asked, surprised, the Luckmanns were millionaires, as rich as croesus, to think that even the tiniest possession had ended up in this dead-end shop...

"That's what he said, yes," the old lady replied.

Katie thought about it for a moment, then asked, "how much?"

"A hundred," the old lady replied.

Katie's eyes almost boggled at the price, this little old lady wanted a hundred bucks for a little statue she all but admitted she'd been given? Okay, it was a nice looking thing, but still...
132.title: To Buy Or Not To Buy

1322.content:
"That's a bit over my budget," Katie said, care to knock it down to sixty?"

"No, but I can do ninety," the old lady replied.

"Sixty five," Katie said.

"Eighty five," The old lady replied, "I've got rent to pay on this place."

"Seventy five," Katie said.

"Eighty, and that's my last offer deary," the old lady replied.

"Okay, eighty it is," Katie replied digging her purse out of her bag and shelling up the cash.

Putting the cash in the till, the old lady handed Katie a heavy paper bag and led her to the front of the store, and handed her the idol, which seemed remarkably heavy for its size, "there you go miss."

"Thanks," Katie said, and headed for the door.

Once out the door Katie...
1322.title: Bargaining

13221.content:
...Spotted a bit of paper blowing around. Cursing at whoever had been careless enough not to put their rubbish in a bin properly, Katie was about to screw it up when she realised it was a five dollar bill. She glanced around to see if anyone was chasing it, and, spotting no-one there, shoved it in her handbag.

A few minutes later, Katie was passing by a lot bookshop. Normally she'd have passed right by it, but then she remembered the bill she'd just picked up, and decided to chance her luck with a couple of scratchcards. Picking 3 cards at random, she stood at the booth and scratched, the first card was a bust, the second got her all of another five bucks, but the last...It took her a moment to realise it, but when she did she almost yahooed, she'd never won a damn thing out of any competition before, and now she'd won a thousand bucks!

Smiling beatifically as she stepped out of the shop, Katie decided to treat herself, after all, she may have just spent eighty bucks on that statue, but it had sure paid off. Stepping out of the shop, she spotted a cancer-society charity stall, normally she wouldn't have bother with such, sure medical research was expensive, but the FDA was funding them wasn't it? Still, she'd just won big, so why not give some away. Pulling out her purse though, she was dismayed to find a real gap in her small-change she had just over half-a-buck in nickels and dimes, and then nothing right up to a lone twenty-buck note and some fifty-bucks. Pity, she wouldn't have minded giving as few bucks, but a whole twenty-note was a bit much really...
13221.title: Lucky Find

13222.content:
...Felt her stomach rubble, urgh, she shouldn't be this hungry this early in the day. For a while, Katie tried to ignore her gut, but within a few minutes it was almost unbearable, and she was forced to give in and head for the nearest source of food, which happened to be a McDonalds. Normally, she'd have steered clear of such a place, but right now the hunger pangs were just too great, so she went in instead.

It was an agonising few minutes wait, but eventually Katie was at the front of the queue, and the girl behind the counter asked, "what would you like?"

Just a filet-o-fish, Katie thought, but somehow it came out as, "A Big Mac thanks." Suddenly, alarm bells started ringing in her head, I don't want that, I can't possibly finish-

"And would you like anything else," the girl asked.

No! though Katie, but again, her mouth seemed to have a mind of its own, "sure, large fries, large coke and a fudge sundae thanks." Before she'd even reached the end of the order she'd zoned out, coming to only when her body, apparently operating on automatic, put the loaded tray down on the table, and seated itself in the booth. Surveying the food, she suddenly felt a touch queasy, there was no way she could finish even the burger, let alone the other stuff. The concerns weren't taken up by the rest of her though, as her body, still intent on doing its own thing, began the meal with gusto.

Katie wasn't normally one to count calories, but she was doing so now, and the numbers were just too big. This didn't seem to concern her body though, which had slowed noticeably since the beginning of the meal, but still seemed intent of finishing every last morsel, which it did, though not before the 20 minute mark. Finally, once the meal was over, whatever had been holding her body in its gluttonous sway finally vanished, though this wasn't much of a comfort, since the size of the meal was such that she couldn't do much more than sit there and rub her over-full stomach, and wonder just what the heck had come over her.

After a few minutes, Katie was finally comfortable enough that she could get up, and so she did, and headed straight for the ladies room, hoping she could purge what she'd just eaten. The hope was quickly dashed though, no matter how much she tried, she couldn't get a single morsel of her meal to come back up. Afterwards, she decided to return home, partly so she could put the statue away, and partly so that she could try to figure out what on earth was going on.

-------

Katie could sense a subtle wrongness the moment she stepped in the door, but couldn't put her finger on it just at the moment. Going to her bedroom, she cleared some room on the dresser for the statue, and then went down to get some antacids. Taking a couple of pills, she went into the kitchen, meaning only to get a glass of water, but her body, again with a mind of its own, opened the cupboard to grab a jumbo packet of potato chips, then hesitated, that shouldn't be there!. She, or rather, her body didn't hesitate for long though, grabbed the bag, and a bottle of coke out of the fridge, and loafed down on the sofa and clicked on the TV. As her body opened the bag, she zoned out again.

-------

Coming to after some time she found...
13222.title: New Appetite

132221.content:
...That it was late afternoon, though just how late she couldn't tell. How many hours had passed she wondered, how long has she been sitting here? Time wasn't Katie's only concern though, for no longer had she she begun to wonder of the time than her stomach rumbled, announcing its hunger to the world. As before, she tried to ignore the grumbling, but once again, within minutes, she was overcome, forced to go into the kitchen to find something, anything to fill the yearning void within her. In her search she completely missed the fact that the trash bag was now rather fuller than it should have been, most of the extra space being food wrappers. She searched for a few moments then selected a packet of chocolate-chip cookies - which her cassandric inner voice told her shouldn't have been there - and another bottle of coke before settling back down on the sofa.

More hours passed as Katie nibbled, first on the cookies, then on another packet of chips that had magically appeared in cupboard. Cookies and chips wouldn't be enough to sustain her though, and so later, her body picked up the phone and ordered a pizza while her mind drifted fitfully, returning to reality only when the delivery boy knocked on the door. Once again, she had to endure the uncomfortable, no, downright scary situation of her body acting apparently of its own volition, scoffing food down like there was no tomorrow.

The Family sized pizza was half-gone when Katie was finally given control of her body again. Storing the rest of the pizza in the fridge, she went into the lounge and turned on the TV again and flipped through the channels, before switching to a romantic movie. Zoning out once again, as the minutes ticked away, she came to just at the end of the movie to find one hand clasped around yet another bottle of coke while the other was finishing off a packet of biscuits.

Terrified at what was happening, but unable to do anything about it, Katie resigned herself to her fate, and watched her body return to the kitchen, drop the now empty bottle into the trash, and the bowl into the sink and then, to her disgust, grab two of the remaining slices of the pizza out of the fridge and scoff them down. After a quick trip to the bathroom to do her ablutions, she got into her pyjamas, which seemed a little looser than they should have been, especially given her recent binging, and climbed into bed - which like the other furniture in the house was now larger and more expensive - and was asleep within minutes.

-------

Katie awoke to the sound of her stomach grumbling...
132221.title: Vanished afternoon

1322212.content:
...The next morning. For a few minutes though, Katie lay there, trying to get her senses back, had she dreamed all of that yesterday, or had she really eaten a feast at McDonalds, and then half a family pizza for dinner? And what about that dream? Strangely, the dream had seemed as real as her other memories, despite the fact that, with the cave and jungle and feast and things, there was no possibly way it could have happened.

Just remembering the dream almost seemed to take her back there; Katie brushed away a hanging vine and wiped her forehead, why had she agreed to go on this crazy mission in the first place, surely there couldn't be anything worth finding out here. Nevertheless she had agreed, so a good idea to make the best of it she thought and grabbing her water-bottle, she took a long drag, before continuing on. Hours must have passed she was sure when she finally came upon the cave.

By now, she was staggering, she'd taken another drag on her water-bottle some time before, but in this humidity it did no good, the sweat just stayed there, wetting her clothes. Still, she'd made it, if this was it, so now all she had to do was grab the statue and she'd be out of here. Moving into the cave, she saw the statue sitting there, and reached out for it-

-------

-and suddenly found herself sprawled on the ground, no, it was too hard to be ground, it felt like stone, but not as cold, what on earth- "Hello young lady."

What, Katie thought mussily, who- "h-hello, wh-who's there?"

"I am," came the voice, rich and full, "and now, so are you."

Looking around for the speaker, Katie suddenly saw her, a fat woman - no, beyond fat, beyond even obese really, the woman was a monster - sitting on a stool in a Greek style that she vaguely remember from history was called a curule, "wh-who are you?"

"I am called, in your language, Fertility" the woman said.

"Fertility," Katie asked, rolling over and standing up, "what sort of name is that?" As she continued to stare the scene just got odder, not only was the floor hard but not cold, the cave, or wherever she was now, faded into blackness quickly, except for where the obese woman was sitting, which seemed to be spotlighted, though despite looking she couldn't spot where the light was coming from.

"It's a description as much as a name," the woman said, "and a description of what I do as much as what I am."

I-I don't understand," Katie stammered.

"No, you wouldn't," the woman said, and stood up, a move which , Katie saw was a bit of a struggle for the woman, but not nearly as much as she would have thought it would be. Once she was standing, the woman came towards the archaeologist in a confident manner that made the thinner woman back off a bit and raise her hands protectively. "Don't worry," she said, "I won't hurt you," and then reached for and undid the buttons on Katie's jacket one after another.

About the third button, Katie - who until then had been just standing there too shocked to move - came to her senses and grabbed the fat woman's wrists to try to stop her going on, but was surprised to find that this didn't even slow the woman down, "what the heck are you doing?"
